data.title: Q&A
data.text:
Tim Henman was born in Oxford in 1974 and began playing tennis on his parents' court aged two. He left school after GCSEs to go on the world junior tennis circuit, and he turned professional in 1993. He will be playing at this year's Wimbledon, which starts on Monday. He is married with two children and lives in Oxfordshire.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

A weekend at home with my family.

What is your greatest fear?

Ill health.

Which living person do you most admire and why?

Bono, for the impact he's had on both his industry and the rest of the world.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

Impatience - and unsolicited advice.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?

In 1995, when I was disqualified from Wimbledon for accidentally hitting a ball girl on the ear.

What is your most treasured possession?

I am not really materialistic, but I'd probably choose our home.

Who would play you in a movie of your life?

Pierce Brosnan.

What is your most unappealing habit?

Eating too quickly.

What is your favourite book?

There's a very limited number to pick from: it would have to be Harry Potter.

Cat or dog?

Dog. We have two black labradors and a cat, but the dogs get the nod.

What is your guiltiest pleasure?

My wine cellar. I don't know that much about wine - the only thing I know for sure is that I like the taste.

What do you owe your parents?

In some respects, everything.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

'Yes' - I should learn to say no more often, so I'd get more time at home.

What is your greatest regret?

When it rained during my 2001 Wimbledon semi-final.

When and where were you happiest?

The days our daughters were born.

What do you consider your greatest achievement?

When I was number four in the world.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Perspective - my job is important but, at the end of the day, it's a game. The health and happiness of my family is what really matters.
